reviewText: I tried to think of how to summarize 4 hours of programming in one sentence. This is the best I could do: People did (and continue to do) things that were legal, rather than things that were right.As usual with Frontline, they give us clear explanations and objective(ish) reporting. I appreciate the ambition and man-hours that went into this program, I only wish that in 4 hours it could have been a bit more insightful or surprising.P.S. - All Frontline programs are available for free online, including this one. There is a Wikipedia page ("List of Frontline (PBS) episodes") with links to and brief descriptions of each.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Frontline has done excellent reporting on a wide variety of subjects, and this four-part series is no exception. It provides an in-depth, detailed, yet understandable account of how and why our banking system failed. I highly recommend this program.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Frontline DVD is one of the most powerful critiques of Wall Street financialization there is.  Though 4 hours barely scratches the surface.  Some historical context would have been useful, such as from 'This Time is Different', or from the sociology of mania 'The Madness of Crowds', or from the prophet of capitalism's self immolation via the insanity of financialization, Karl Marx.  The 10,000 foot view is that Wall Street's game of profiting off of selling off truly productive enterprise to the globalization mania left it short of stuff to sell, so it had to invent something out of thin air, i.e. derivatives and CDOs based on the last remaining hard asset: housing.  That game had a short life however.  Now Wall Street is 40% of corporate profit, so the tail is wagging the dog, wall street is now irrelevant to truly productive enterprise, and is generating only parasitical unproductive derivatives.  As Marx said, Financialization is the End Stage of Capitalism.  One wonders which corporate sponsors Frontline managed to assemble for this painful psychoanalysis of their corrupt world.
summary: Excellent but no credit to Karl Marx for predicting Financialization as the End Stage of Capitalism
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just watched the first two hour episode and it was very well done. If anyone has seen the movie "Margin Call", then the way in which this program is made will look familiar.  It is very theatrically done. That does not make it wrong but it means you need to be versed in the history to sift the drama (lots of panoramic camera sweeps over New York skyscrapers and shiny black limos carrying important people racing to tense meetings in Washington and Wall Street),  from the facts.  One of the problems with the 'facts' is who they interviewed in the program.  Here we have such accomplices to the crime as Representative Barney ('lets roll the dice one more time') Frank and Senator Chris ('sweetheart mortgage  from Countrywide') Dodd expressing their 'shock and outrage' over the behavior of the bankers.  Give me a break !! And then there's Nancy Pelosi expressing her opinion. Enough said. Actually the most interesting interviews are of the young JP Morgan analysts (people never before seen) who invented CDO's in the first place and the perfectly logical reason for doing so.  That was smart of the producers because it sets the background for catastrophe that follows.  As usual Will Lyman's grave narration is effective for these kinds of big insider, econo/politico exposes.  I'm looking foreward two the second part next week.  So far so good.
